title: Bitopological space
summary: In mathematics, a bitopological space is a set endowed with two topologies. Typically, if the set is X {\displaystyle X} and the topologies are σ {\displaystyle \sigma } and τ {\displaystyle \tau } then the bitopological space is referred to as ( X , σ , τ ) {\displaystyle (X,\sigma ,\tau )} . The notion was introduced by J. C. Kelly in the study of quasimetrics, i.e. distance functions that are not required to be symmetric.
